publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhleduring T III Š 72.15

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and translation are based on .

Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).

seg.seg: they say to each other: we [are] here the ones enjoying the riches gathered by our father and because of [this] power
Wir [sind] hier die von unserem Vater gesammelten Besitztümer genießend und werden durch die Macht des Prinzentums im ganzen Land als Herrschaft gepriesen.
We [are] here enjoying the possessions gathered by our father, und due to the power of princedom we are praised as rulers all over the land.
also in all the country we are praised as master. (Therefore) this our statement[s] is not to be checked: which is superior, which is inferior? When
When we go into another country, then it will be possible to check our statement[s].
we go into another country, then it will be possible to check our statement[s]. Therefore we,
leaving our own (land), to do a deed, will go from one country to another. All said: Let us make it so. Thereupon the princes of the[ir] father,
(the king, took their leave), and without money [they] went away from their own country into a country of others. While each of them (was) striving there for himself,
prince (Vīryavān), having seen, in another great water, a sandal tree floating along the stream, due to his strength
Als Prinz (Vīryavān) in einem fremden großen Wasser einen Sandelbaum [wtl. Sandelholz] im Strombett(?) treiben sah, zog er ihn (durch) seine Kraft (ohne Mühe) heraus. Dadurch erwarb er Geld.
When Prince (Vīryavān) saw, in a great foreign water, sandalwood float in the riverbed(?), he pulled it out (without effort because of) his great strength. Therefrom he gained money.
(without effort) pulled it out. Thereby he gained property. Śilpavān, too, delighting the people with making music on [his] lute,
Auch Śilpavān, durch Lautenmusikmachen die Menschen (erfreuend), erwarb Geld.
Śilpavān, too, (delighting) the people by making lute music, acquired money.
gained property. Rūpavān, by giving pleasure to the most beautiful girls and women with the capability of his body,
profit he kept gathering. Prajñāvān, too, by pleasing very great, rich merchants with his wisdom,
Auch Prajñāvān erlangte Geld, indem er ganz große Reiche [und] Kaufleute (durch) [seine] Klugheit erfreute.
Prajñāvān, too, obtained money, by pleasing very great rich ones [and] merchants (with) [his] sagacity.
gained possessions. Now in this country the king had died, and another, who should become king, was not (there).
The ministers, people of the country, chancellors and the wise ones, who all of them had recognized prince Puṇyavān’s splendour,

Die Minister, Leute des Landes, Kanzler [und] Gelehrte, die insgesamt Prinz Punyavānas Glanz erkannt hatten, lobten [und] priesen [ihn], vollzogen [wtl. machten] Punyavāns Salbung [und] machten ihn sich zum König in dem Lande.

The ministers, the people of the land, chancellors [and] scholars, who had all together realized prince Punyavāna's glory, lauded [and] praised [him), performed [lit. made] the anointing of Punyavāna [and] made him king of the country for themselves.
performed the anointment of Puṇyavān and made him king of the country. || In the R.-tune: || See
Sehet die Kraft der Tugendhaftigkeit [wtl. der Verdienste]! Sie führt dahin, wo das Glück [ist].
See the power of merits! It leads to where happiness [is].

p.note: The translation is largely based on 18-19, and .

The leaf number on the margin has been lost, but a number 70 (sic!) is written inside the string hole of the verso side by a different hand. Since this leaf stands in a continuous series, it actually ought to have the leaf number 79. The combination of lost margin and deviating string-hole numbering continues until .

div.p: Edition12-13. Siegling's personal copy of p. 12 p. 13.

list.item: a1 – _k\ āla_m\ wcac t_r_aṅkiñcä\ wa_s\ tṣaṃ pācri ṣñi kākropun_t\ a_k_aṃtsuneyäntu wärpnāmāṃ _m_aśkituneṣiṃ na – a2 śkaṃ poñcäṃ ypeyaṃ kākmar_t\ _p_allāmt_r_a – – _s_a_s\ wa_s_aṃ weñlune mā _k_arsā_l\ ke śpālmeṃ ke wärce äntā – a3 –_s\ ālu ype _k_alkā_m_a_s\ tmann at_s\ ṣakk at_s\ wa_s_aṃ weñlune _k_arsāl tā_ṣ\ _t_amyo wa_s\ ṣñi – a4 – – smāṃ yalis mosaṃ ālu ype picä\ poś t_r_aṅki _t_amne pyā_m_a_s\ • _t_m_a_ṣ\ cem _m_aśkitāñä\ pāca· l·– a5 – – – – _ṣ\ sne a_k_aṃtsune ṣñi ypeyä_ṣ\ lo_k\ ālu ype kalka_r\ || tmaṃ ce_m letkā_r\ skenmāṃ – a6 – – – – śki_t\ āla_k_añcaṃ tsopat_s_aṃ wraṃ candaṃṣiṃ or lakā ymāṃ _p_alko_r_a_ṣ\ ca_m _s_a_m\ ṣñi wä – – b1 – – – – – tskā_s\ _t_amyo a_k_aṃtsune kropñā_t\ || śilpavāṃ penu t_s_ar_k\ rape yāmluneyo wras[a] – b2 – – – – ·sune kropñā_t\ || rupavāṃ śpālmeṃ śpālun_t\ kānikāñcā_s\ k_ulewā_s\ ampātṣiṃ yātluneyo (–) b3 – – _t_k_asmāṃ niṣpa_l\ kropñā_t\ || prajñavāṃ penu śāwe_s\ śāwe_s\ dhani_s\ śriṣṭhi_s\ knānmune – b4 ·ā_t_k_asmāṃ a_k_aṃtsune śālpa_t\ || _t_m_a_ṣ\ ca_m\ ypeyaṃ wä_l\ w_l_a_s\ wäl na_s_a_l\ ālak mā ṣe – (–) b5 āmāśāñä\ ypeṣiñi wrasañä\ puro – tāñä\ knānmā_n_a_ṣ\ p_ukā_k\ puṇyavāṃ _m_aśkite parnore _k_arso – b6 _ṣ\ ārtan_t\ pālan_t\ puṇyavāni abhiṣe – yām_r_a ca_m\ ypeyaṃ lāṃt yāmtsāṃ_t_aṃ || ratisāyakaṃ || _p_a –

The translation is largely based on [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 18-19, and [[Carling, DThTA]].

b6. The tune has 4x14 syllables, rhythm 7/7.

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a2-3 When we go into another country, then it will be possible to check our statement[s]. 245


Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a1-2 Wir [sind] hier die von unserem Vater gesammelten Besitztümer genießend und werden durch die Macht des Prinzentums im ganzen Land als Herrschaft gepriesen. 245
a6-b1 Als Prinz (Vīryavān) in einem fremden großen Wasser einen Sandelbaum [wtl. Sandelholz] im Strombett(?) treiben sah, zog er ihn (durch) seine Kraft (ohne Mühe) heraus. Dadurch erwarb er Geld. 439
b1-2 Auch Śilpavān, durch Lautenmusikmachen die Menschen (erfreuend), erwarb Geld. 401
b3-4 Auch Prajñāvān erlangte Geld, indem er ganz große Reiche [und] Kaufleute (durch) [seine] Klugheit erfreute. 197
b5-6 Die Minister, Leute des Landes, Kanzler [und] Gelehrte, die insgesamt Prinz Punyavānas Glanz erkannt hatten, lobten [und] priesen [ihn], vollzogen [wtl. machten] Punyavāns Salbung [und] machten ihn sich zum König in dem Lande. 80-1, 86, 169, 429
b6-a1 Sehet die Kraft der Tugendhaftigkeit [wtl. der Verdienste]! Sie führt dahin, wo das Glück [ist]. 390-1


line b2: a(rä)mpātṣiṃ yātlune-yo translated as “by the perfection of the beauty” in [[Carling, DThTA]]: 20; the whole sentence down to the first half of line b3 (rupavāṃ to niṣpal kropñāt ), however, is translated as above on p. 141, with the line break restored to yātluneyo (lyutār kā)tkäsmāṃ. Please check! (TI)

a2 (translation): ke is a genitive form, so we should probably translate it as whose (as does [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 18). (BK)

The leaf number on the margin has been lost, but a number 70 (sic!) is written inside the string hole of the verso side by a different hand. Since this leaf stands in a continuous series, it actually ought to have the leaf number 79. The combination of lost margin and deviating string-hole numbering continues until [[A 24]].

nunak|(nu)|(na)k a1 ālam wcac träṅkiñc was tṣaṃ pācri_(Gen.)|pācri ṣñi kākropunt akäṃtsuneyäntu wärpnāmāṃ mäśkituneṣiṃ na – a2 śkaṃ poñcäṃ ypeyaṃ kākmart pällāmträ – – säs wasäṃ weñlune mā_(TA)|mā kärsāl ke śpālmeṃ_(TA)|śpālmeṃ ke wärce äntā(ne) a3 (wa)s ālu ype kälkāmäs tmann ats ṣakk ats wasäṃ weñlune kärsāl tāṣ tämyo was ṣñi – a4 – – smāṃ yalis mosaṃ ālu ype pic poś träṅki tämne pyāmäs • tmäṣ cem mäśkitāñ pāca(r) l·– a5 – – – – ṣ sne akäṃtsune ṣñi ypeyäṣ lok ālu ype kalkar || tmaṃ cem letkār skenmāṃ – a6 (viryavāṃ) (mä)śkit ālakäñcaṃ tsopatsäṃ wraṃ candaṃṣiṃ or_(TA)|or lakā ymāṃ pälkoräṣ cam säm ṣñi wä – – b1 – – – – – tskās tämyo akäṃtsune kropñāt || śilpavāṃ penu tsärk rape yāmluneyo wrasa – b2 – – (akäṃt)sune kropñāt || rupavāṃ śpālmeṃ_(TA)|śpālmeṃ śpālunt kānikāñcās k_ulewās a«rä»mpātṣiṃ yātluneyo – b3 – – tkäsmāṃ niṣpal kropñāt || prajñavāṃ penu śāwes śāwes dhanis śriṣṭhis knānmune(yo) b4 (k)ātkäsmāṃ akäṃtsune śālpat || tmäṣ cam ypeyaṃ wäl wläs wäl nasäl ālak mā_(TA)|mā ṣe(ṣ) – b5 āmāśāñ ypeṣiñi wrasañ puro(hi)tāñ knānmānäṣ p_ukāk puṇyavāṃ mäśkite parnore kärsoräṣ|kärso(rä)|ṣ b6 ārtant pālant puṇyavāni abhiṣe(k) yāmrä cam ypeyaṃ lāṃt yāmtsāṃtäṃ || ratisāyakaṃ || # pälkāc|pä(lkā|c) #1a

a1 they say to each other: we [are] here the ones enjoying the riches gathered by our father and because of [this] power a2 also in all the country we are praised as master. (Therefore) this our statement[s] is not to be checked: which is superior, which is inferior? When a3 we go into another country, then it will be possible to check our statement[s]. Therefore we, a4 leaving our own (land), to do a deed, will go from one country to another. All said: Let us make it so. Thereupon the princes of the[ir] father, a5 (the king, took their leave), and without money [they] went away from their own country into a country of others. While each of them (was) striving there for himself, a6 prince (Vīryavān), having seen, in another great water, a sandal tree floating along the stream, due to his strength b1 (without effort) pulled it out. Thereby he gained property. Śilpavān, too, delighting the people with making music on [his] lute, b2 gained property. Rūpavān, by giving pleasure to the most beautiful girls and women with the capability of his body, b3 profit he kept gathering. Prajñāvān, too, by pleasing very great, rich merchants with his wisdom, b4 gained possessions. Now in this country the king had died, and another, who should become king, was not (there). b5 The ministers, people of the country, chancellors and the wise ones, who all of them had recognized prince Puṇyavān’s splendour, b6 performed the anointment of Puṇyavān and made him king of the country. || In the R.-tune: || See

div.p: line : a(rä)mpātṣiṃ yātlune-yo translated as “by the perfection of the beauty” in <citedRange>20</citedRange></bibl>; the whole sentence down to the first half of line b3 (<hi>rupavāṃ</hi> to <hi>niṣpal kropñāt </hi>), however, is translated as above on p. 141, with the line break restored to <hi>yātluneyo (lyutār kā)tkäsmāṃ</hi>. Please check! (TI)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a2"/> (translation): <hi>ke</hi> is a genitive form, so we should probably translate it as <hi>whose</hi> (as does <bibl><title corresp="ref:sieg1944"/><citedRange>18</citedRange></bibl>). (BK)</p></project_comment>
